newsitem.title: FRANCE: Airbus signs A3XX accords with two firms.
newsitem.headline: Airbus signs A3XX accords with two firms.

text.p: European planemaking consortium Airbus said on Friday it signed memoranda of understanding with Belgium's Belairbus and The Netherlands's Fokker Aviation on the study phase of the A3XX large aircraft project.
Airbus Industrie said the accords were signed with a view to Belairbus and Fokker becoming risk sharing partners in the A3XX programme.
The memoranda were expected to lead to a business agreement which would represent about $2 billion in business for Belairbus and Fokker, Airbus said.
"This is a first step for closer cooperation between the aircraft industries of the two countries and Airbus Industrie," an Airbus statement said.
Airbus said engineers from Fokker and Belairbus will be integrated in the A3XX programme.
"Participation in this phase will allow Belairbus and Fokker Aviation to evaluate the extent of their involvement in future phases of the A3XX programme," Airbus said.
Airbus said it was continuing talks with other aerospace companies around the world, with the aim of placing a total of up to 40 percent of the A3XX work content with risk sharing partners.
Both Fokker, a unit of Stork NV, and Belairbus have been associate members of the Airbus consortium on specific aircraft programmes since the late seventies.

Airbus is a consortium made up of French state-owned Ste Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, British Aerospace Plc, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, a unit of Daimler-Benz AG and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA (CASA) of Spain.
Planemaker Fokker NV, in which Daimler-Benz Aerospace held a 51 percent stake and which cut off financial support in January 1996, went bankrupt last year.
